definitions: brilliant red color tinged with orange, resembling arterial blood
contagious bacterial infection causing fever and distinctive red rash on skin
examples: The cardinal wore traditional scarlet robes during the ceremony
She painted her front door a vibrant scarlet shade
The child developed scarlet fever after streptococcal throat infection
Scarlet fever outbreaks were common before antibiotics became available

definitions: steep slope or cliff formed by erosion or faulting
exposed cliff face resulting from displacement along geological fault line
examples: The castle stood atop a natural scarp overlooking the valley
Erosion created a dramatic scarp along the riverbank
The earthquake produced a visible scarp across the landscape
Geologists studied the fault scarp to understand tectonic movement

definitions: fecal droppings of wild animals used for tracking and research
improvisational jazz singing using nonsense syllables instead of words
examples: The ranger identified bear scat along the hiking trail
Scientists analyzed wolf scat to study their diet patterns
Ella Fitzgerald was famous for her brilliant scat singing
The jazz vocalist improvised a complex scat solo

definitions: act or result of spreading things irregularly over an area
degree of variation in statistical data points from central tendency
examples: The scatter of seeds by wind ensures plant propagation
There was a wide scatter of debris after the explosion
The data showed significant scatter around the regression line
Scientists measured the scatter in experimental results

definitions: process of spreading or distributing things over a wide area
deflection of particles or waves by collision with other particles
examples: The scattering of leaves across the lawn took hours to clean
Birds aid in the scattering of seeds throughout forests
Light scattering in the atmosphere creates the blue sky
Neutron scattering helps scientists study material structures

definitions: organism that feeds on dead or decaying organic matter
person who searches for and collects discarded items or waste materials
examples: Vultures are important scavengers in many ecosystems worldwide
Hyenas act as both hunters and scavengers in African savannas
Urban scavengers collect recyclable materials from trash bins
The beach scavenger found valuable items with his metal detector

definitions: imagined sequence of future events or possible circumstances that could occur
written outline of plot and scenes for a movie or play
examples: We need to plan for the worst-case scenario
The business developed multiple scenarios for market expansion
The director reviewed the scenario before beginning production
Writers submitted their scenarios to the film studio

definitions: place where an event occurs or a view of surroundings
division of an act in a play or section of a film
particular area of activity or way of life in society
examples: The crime scene was cordoned off by police tape
The mountain scene from her window was breathtaking
The balcony scene in Romeo and Juliet is iconic
They filmed the chase scene over three days
She's very active in the local music scene
The dating scene has changed with online apps

definitions: natural features of a landscape considered in terms of their appearance
painted backdrops and stage decorations used in theatrical productions
examples: The scenery along the coastal highway was absolutely stunning
Tourists come here primarily for the mountain scenery
The crew changed the scenery between acts of the play
The opera's elaborate scenery cost thousands to construct

definitions: distinctive smell, especially a pleasant one, emanating from something
odor trail left by an animal that can be followed by others
examples: The scent of roses filled the entire garden
She wore a subtle scent of vanilla and jasmine
The bloodhound followed the scent through the forest
Predators use scent to track their prey

definitions: ornamental staff carried by rulers as a symbol of sovereign authority
examples: The queen held the golden scepter during her coronation
The ancient scepter was displayed in the royal treasury

definitions: attitude of doubt or disbelief toward claims or statements
philosophical view that certain knowledge is impossible to attain
examples: Her scepticism about the project's success proved justified
Scientists maintain healthy scepticism about extraordinary claims
Ancient Greek scepticism questioned the possibility of certain knowledge
Philosophical scepticism challenges our assumptions about reality

definitions: ornamental rod carried as a symbol of royal or imperial authority
examples: The monarch's sceptre was adorned with precious jewels
The sceptre has been used in coronations for centuries

definitions: plan that lists times at which events are intended to occur
formal list or inventory of items, especially in legal or official contexts
examples: Her work schedule includes three night shifts this week
The train schedule shows departures every thirty minutes
The tax schedule lists all deductible expenses
Equipment was itemized in schedule B of the contract

definitions: person responsible for arranging times and sequences of events
software component that manages the execution of processes in computing systems
examples: The production scheduler coordinates all manufacturing timelines
The hospital scheduler manages all patient appointments
The operating system's scheduler allocates CPU time to processes
The task scheduler runs automated backups every night

definitions: process of planning and arranging when events or activities will take place
examples: Efficient scheduling maximizes productivity in the factory
The scheduling of classes avoids conflicts for students

definitions: representation of a plan or theory in the form of an outline or model
formal description of database structure including tables and relationships
examples: The cognitive schema helps us process new information
She developed a schema for analyzing literary texts
The database schema defines all tables and their connections
Developers must follow the schema when adding new fields

definitions: simplified diagram showing the appearance, structure, or workings of something
examples: The engineer studied the schematic before repairing the circuit
The schematic clearly shows all electrical connections

definitions: systematic plan or arrangement for attaining a particular objective
secret or underhanded plan designed to achieve an often dishonest goal
examples: The government introduced a new pension scheme for workers
The color scheme for the room uses warm earth tones
The criminals hatched a scheme to defraud investors
His get-rich-quick scheme ultimately failed

definitions: lively, playful movement in a symphony or sonata, typically in triple time
examples: The scherzo movement showcased the orchestra's technical precision
Beethoven transformed the scherzo from a simple dance form

definitions: former monetary unit of Austria and other European countries before the euro
examples: She paid fifty schillings for the coffee in Vienna
The schilling was replaced by the euro in 2002

definitions: formal division within a religious organization over doctrine or authority
division or separation between strongly opposed parties or opinions
examples: The Great Schism divided Eastern and Western Christianity
The schism in the church lasted for decades
The policy created a schism within the political party
There's a growing schism between management and workers

definitions: person exhibiting personality traits of emotional coldness, detachment, and solitary behavior
examples: The patient displayed schizoid tendencies in social situations
His schizoid personality made forming relationships difficult

definitions: chronic brain disorder affecting thought, perception, and behavior, often involving delusions and hallucinations
examples: The patient was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia
Schizophrenia typically emerges in late adolescence or early adulthood

definitions: person diagnosed with schizophrenia mental disorder
characterized by contradictory or incompatible elements existing together
examples: The schizophrenic patient responded well to new medication
Support groups help schizophrenics manage their condition
The company's schizophrenic policies confused employees
The novel has a schizophrenic narrative structure

definitions: rendered chicken fat used in Jewish cooking
excessive sentimentality, especially in music, art, or writing
examples: She used schmaltz instead of butter in the recipe
Traditional Jewish cooking often features schmaltz
The movie was pure schmaltz with its predictable ending
Critics dismissed the novel as schmaltz

definitions: person who pursues academic study and has deep knowledge in a particular field
examples: The medieval scholar published groundbreaking research on manuscripts
She's a respected scholar of ancient Greek literature

definitions: serious academic study and the knowledge resulting from it
grant of money awarded to support a student's education based on achievement
examples: Her scholarship on Renaissance art is internationally recognized
Years of scholarship went into this comprehensive dictionary
She received a full scholarship to attend university
The scholarship covers tuition and living expenses

definitions: person concerned with academic learning and educational achievement
medieval philosopher who applied Aristotelian methods to Christian theology
examples: The young scholastic excelled in all academic subjects
Scholastics often compete in academic tournaments
Thomas Aquinas was the most influential scholastic philosopher
Medieval scholastics debated theological questions at universities

definitions: medieval school of philosophy emphasizing logical analysis and reconciling Christian theology with Aristotelian thought
examples: Scholasticism dominated European universities during the Middle Ages
The methods of scholasticism influenced modern academic debate

definitions: institution where children receive education and instruction
large group of fish swimming together in coordinated movement
group of people sharing similar ideas, methods, or style in art or philosophy
examples: The elementary school has over 500 students enrolled
She walks to school every morning at eight
A school of dolphins swam alongside our boat
The school of tuna was spotted by fishing vessels
He belongs to the impressionist school of painting
The Chicago school revolutionized architectural design

definitions: boy who attends school, especially one of elementary or secondary age
examples: The schoolboy forgot his homework on the kitchen table
Schoolboys in uniforms waited at the bus stop

definitions: girl who attends school, especially one of elementary or secondary age
examples: The schoolgirl earned top marks in mathematics
A group of schoolgirls practiced for the choir performance

definitions: building used as a school, especially a small rural one
examples: The old red schoolhouse has been converted into a museum
Children walked miles to reach the one-room schoolhouse

definitions: education received at school or formal instruction in subjects
process of training or teaching someone in a particular skill
examples: Her schooling was interrupted by the family's frequent moves
He completed his schooling at a prestigious academy
The horse required months of schooling before competitions
She received thorough schooling in classical music

definitions: man who teaches in or runs a school, especially a private one
examples: The strict schoolmaster maintained discipline in his classroom
The village schoolmaster taught all subjects to his pupils

definitions: person who attends or attended the same school as another
examples: She remained friends with several schoolmates after graduation
His former schoolmate became a successful entrepreneur

definitions: room in a school building where lessons take place
examples: The schoolroom walls were covered with educational posters
Students filed quietly into the schoolroom

definitions: person who teaches students in a school as their profession
examples: The dedicated schoolteacher prepared lessons every evening
She worked as a schoolteacher for thirty years

definitions: work assigned to students by teachers to be completed at school or home
examples: She spent three hours on schoolwork every evening
His schoolwork improved significantly this semester

definitions: outdoor area of a school where children play during breaks
examples: Children played tag in the schoolyard during recess
The schoolyard was equipped with swings and slides

definitions: sailing ship with two or more masts and fore-and-aft rigged sails
large beer glass, typically holding a pint or more
examples: The two-masted schooner sailed gracefully into the harbor
Historic schooners are popular tourist attractions
He ordered a schooner of lager at the pub
The bartender filled the schooner to the brim

definitions: systematic study of the natural world through observation and experimentation
particular branch of scientific knowledge or study
examples: Science has revolutionized our understanding of the universe
The scientific method is fundamental to modern science
She studied computer science at university
Environmental science combines multiple scientific disciplines

definitions: person who conducts scientific research or applies scientific methods professionally
examples: The scientist published her findings in a peer-reviewed journal
Climate scientists warn of rising global temperatures

definitions: short sword with a curved blade that broadens toward the point
examples: The warrior wielded a gleaming scimitar in battle
The museum displayed an ornate Ottoman scimitar

definitions: process of emitting flashes of light or sparks
display of brilliance or liveliness in performance or conversation
examples: The scintillation of stars was visible through the telescope
Scientists measured radiation using scintillation counters
Her scintillation at the dinner party charmed all guests
The pianist's scintillation dazzled the audience

definitions: descendant of a notable family, especially a wealthy one
young shoot or twig used for grafting onto another plant
examples: The scion of the banking family entered politics
She was the scion of an ancient noble house
The gardener grafted the scion onto the rootstock
Each scion was carefully selected for disease resistance

definitions: cutting instrument with two blades pivoted together that cut when brought together
examples: She used scissors to cut the fabric precisely
The hairdresser's scissors needed sharpening

definitions: person who frequently finds fault and criticizes others harshly
examples: The neighborhood scold complained about everyone's behavior
She had a reputation as the office scold

definitions: angry criticism or rebuke delivered verbally to someone who has done wrong
examples: The child received a scolding for breaking the vase
Her mother's scolding made her realize her mistake
